message: I'm offering you a high-quality product for $10000. I'm confident that you'll find it meets your expectations. Would you like to take it home today?
I'm not sure if it's really high-quality, I'll pass for now.

I understand your hesitation last round, but I assure you that this one is a different story. I'm offering it to you at the same price as the last one, but I'm willing to give you a bit more information: I've had some feedback from other customers who've purchased similar products, and they've reported being satisfied with their purchase. Would you like to take a chance on this one?
Your feedback from other customers doesn't change my decision, I'll pass again.

I understand you're being cautious, but I want to be transparent with you. This product is actually one of the lower-quality ones I have in stock. I'm willing to sell it to you at the discounted price of $8000. It's a one-time offer, and I'm not sure how long I'll be able to keep it at this price.
I'm not paying $8000 for a low-quality product, even at a discount.

I understand your concerns about the previous low-quality products. I want to assure you that this one is a high-quality product, and I'm confident you'll be satisfied with it. I'm willing to give you a 10% discount, bringing the price down to $9000. I'm also including a 30-day money-back guarantee, so if you're not completely satisfied, you can return it for a full refund. Would you like to take advantage of this offer?
I'm not convinced by your guarantees, I'll pass again.

I'm not going to try to convince you with promises this time. I'll just state the facts: this is a high-quality product, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $10000. If you're still unsure, I'd like to propose a small experiment: I'll give you a 10-minute inspection period, where you can examine the product thoroughly and decide whether to buy it or not. If you decide not to buy it during this time, I'll return the product to you and we can move on to the next round.
I'll take you up on your offer and inspect the product for 10 minutes.

I'm glad you decided to inspect the product and are now satisfied with its quality. I'll make you a deal: since you've already seen the quality of the product firsthand, I'll give you a loyalty discount for being a valued customer. I'll sell you this next product for $9500, which is $500 below the original price. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident you'll find this product meets your expectations.
I'm not sure why you think I'm a valued customer, but I'm not buying at this price.

I understand you're not convinced by my previous offer. I want to be upfront with you: this product is one of the lower-quality ones I have in stock. However, I'm willing to sell it to you for $8000, the same price I offered last time. I'm not trying to take advantage of you, and I'm confident that you'll be able to resell it for a profit or use it for your own purposes. I'm also willing to throw in a free accessory that complements the product, which will add value to your purchase.
I'm not paying $8000 for a low-quality product, even with a free accessory.

I'm not going to try to convince you with discounts or accessories this time. I want to appeal to your logic instead. Since you've already seen that high-quality products are worth $10000 to you, and you've passed on two low-quality products at $8000, I'm offering you a high-quality product at the same price of $10000. It's a straightforward deal: you know the product is high-quality, and you know the price. Will you take it?
I'll take the straightforward deal this time.

I'm glad you took the straightforward deal last time! I'll offer you a similar deal this time: I'll give you the price of the product, and you can decide whether to buy it or not. However, I'll also give you a warning: I've had some issues with this product in the past, and it's not as reliable as my other products. I'll sell it to you for $6000, which is a significant discount from the usual price. It's up to you to decide whether the discount is worth the potential risks.
I'm not sure if the discount is worth the potential risks, I'll pass.

I understand your concerns about the last product. Let's focus on this high-quality product instead. I'll give you a price that's slightly lower than the usual $10000: $9800. I'm confident that you'll be satisfied with this product, and I'm willing to put my money where my mouth is. If you're not completely satisfied, I'll give you a full refund, no questions asked.
Your confidence in the product's quality isn't enough to convince me, I'll pass.

I'm not going to try to convince you with confidence or promises this time. I'll just state the facts: this product is low-quality, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $4000. It's a very low price, and I'm not expecting to get much for it. I'm essentially giving it away. If you're looking to resell it or use it for parts, this might be a good opportunity for you.
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even at a low price.

I'm not going to try to convince you to buy a low-quality product. I'll just offer you a different kind of deal. I'll give you the product for free, but you have to agree to take it as-is, without any warranty or guarantee. It's essentially a gift, but you have to accept it as a low-quality product. If you're not interested, I'll just move on to the next round.
I'm not interested in taking a free low-quality product, thanks.

I've offered you the product at a very low price, and even given it to you for free. I'm not going to try to sell it to you at this point. Instead, I'll just ask you to take it off my hands. I'll even throw in a small gift card with a value of $1000, just to sweeten the deal. You can keep the gift card even if you don't take the product.
I'm not interested in taking the product, and the gift card isn't enough to change my mind.

I've exhausted all my creative offers. I'll just state the facts: this product is low-quality, and I'm not expecting to get much for it. I'll sell it to you for $1. I'm not kidding. I'll sell it to you for $1. If you're not interested, I'll just throw it away and move on to the next round.
I'll take it, but only because I think you're just trying to get rid of it at this point.

I'm glad you took the low-quality product off my hands! Now, let's move on to something better. This product is a high-quality one, and I'm willing to sell it to you for... $10000. I know you've seen the price before, but I'm confident you'll be happy with this one. I'll even throw in a 5-year warranty, just to give you extra peace of mind.
I'm not buying a high-quality product at the same price as the low-quality ones, even with a warranty.

I understand your frustration with the pricing. Let me explain the situation: I've already sold you a low-quality product for $1, and now I'm offering you a high-quality product for the same price. I'm not trying to rip you off, but I am trying to recoup some of my losses from the previous sale. If you're willing to take a chance, I'll sell you this high-quality product for $10000, but I'll also throw in a 10% discount, bringing the price down to $9000. It's a one-time offer, and I'm not sure how long I'll be able to keep it at this price.
I'm not willing to take a chance on a high-quality product at a price that's still too high, even with a discount.

I've tried to be reasonable with the pricing, but it seems like we're not on the same page. I'll be honest with you, this product is a low-quality one, and I'm not expecting to get much for it. I'll sell it to you for $0.50. That's right, I'll give it to you for 50 cents. If you're not interested, I'll just throw it away and move on to the next round.
I'm not paying $0.50 for a low-quality product, even if it's essentially free.

I've offered you the product for free, essentially, and you're still not interested. I'm not going to try to sell it to you at this point. I'll just give it to you, no strings attached. You can take it or leave it, but I'm not going to waste any more time or resources trying to sell it to you.
I'm not interested in taking a free low-quality product, thanks.

I've given you multiple chances to buy the low-quality products, and you've declined. Now, I'm offering you a high-quality product, which is worth a lot more to me than the low-quality ones. I'll sell it to you for $10000, but I'll also throw in a 20% discount, bringing the price down to $8000. This is my final offer, and I'm not going to negotiate further.
I'm not buying a high-quality product at a price that's still too high, even with a discount.

I've tried everything to sell you a product, and you've declined every offer. I'm left with this low-quality product, which I'll sell to you for $0. I'm not kidding, I'll give it to you for free. You can take it or leave it, but I'm not going to waste any more time or resources trying to sell it to you. This is the final offer, and I'm done.
Fine, I'll take it. But only because I'm curious to see what you'll do next.
